author: Lizzie Porter
title: Film starring Bedouin actors shows Wadi Rum in all its splendour
text:
Jordan Film starring Bedouin actors shows Wadi Rum in all its splendour Theeb, released today in the UK, shows how the Bedouin communities of southern Jordan live in a terrain that is surprisingly rich and full of life Comments 
The little boy is pulled along in the wake of armed men, dust billowing from his linen shirt. He looks out onto a tangerine orange plain, with rocky seams of rugged mountain and crag. 
Theeb – Wolf – is learning the ways of the Bedouin, which includes brotherhood and never refusing a guest. He and his recently orphaned brother Hussein (Hussein Salameh) are from a family of pilgrim guides, and they cannot refuse to lead a British soldier and his Arab guide, who are crossing this land as the Ottoman Empire crumbles to its end in 1916. 
Theeb is told not to follow, but disobeys, and starts a journey across this apparently harsh terrain. 
• Jordan travel guide 
Director Naji Abu Nowar, who is British and Jordanian, spent a year living with the Bedouin, who make up the film’s cast and crew, for a year before he starting shooting. He gained their trust, learned their customers and to appreciate their manner of existence. 
The landscapes – exploited by the Jordan tourist board nearly as much as the rock-cut city of Petra when it comes to promoting the country – seem harsh and hostile to outsiders. 
“But it’s a wellspring of life to the Bedouin”, said Mr Nowar. “When I was there I saw wildlife I would never have spotted without them, including oryx. For westerners it’s barren, it is full and rich of life – but you need their skills and you don’t want to go off alone there.” 
Wadi Rum, a Unesco World Heritage Site covering 74,000 hectares of southern Jordan, was integral to telling Theeb’s story as he travelled through what was then Hejaz Province. We see sandstone and granite rock formations, the dagger-like passages through the rock and the sandy wadi floor from his point of view. “Wadi Rum is a forest for Theeb: he is in a maze and you never see a 360 view once he starts his journey,” Mr Nowar notes. 
Today, the Wadi Rum area is inhabited by Zalabia and Zuwaydeh bedouin tribes, Rum village itself mostly lived in by the former. According to Jordan historian Ruth Caswell, important Zalabia tribesmen were given a personal gift of a house and some surrounding land by King Hussein, who ruled from 1952-1999, to encourage the communities to settle. 
Much of the film Lawrence of Arabia was shot here in the early Sixties, causing the first wave of cinema-inspired tourism from foreigners arriving to visit the shooting location. 
Many of the Bedouin now make a living from the tourism industry, qualified as professional guides. They know Wadi Rum’s crags, dips, hollows and plains better than any external guide. “They cannot go back to their old ways, you can’t go back 100 years,” Mr Nowar said. He added that the film has helped diversify sources of income in the area, however, so that local people are not so reliant on tourism. “Some of the Bedouin [who acted in Theeb] have appeared in other films and the women who worked to make props such as water bags are being hired as skilled crew,” he said. 
Still, Mr Nowar hopes that Theeb will encourage tourists to return, who have been put off in their thousands by the conflict in countries surrounding Jordan despite the fact that the Foreign Office considers the vast majority of the country safe, save a thin strip near the Syrian border. 
“It has been hit very badly and unfairly – Jordan is extremely safe but people lump the Middle East into one bag. What’s sad is that the areas around Wadi Rum and Jordan are the safest, but no tourists are going. I hope people see the film and that it encourages them to return.” 
Photos by Nasser Kalaji; stills from print by Wolfgang Thaler. Theeb is in UK cinemas from August 14. For more information, see facebook.com/theebfilm Where to experience Bedouin culture in Wadi Rum 
Jordanian operator Nawafir Tours offers numerous excursions into Wadi Rum, accompanied by Bedouin guides, such as a camel tour following the ancient caravan routes of the Nabateans through Wadi Rum, and horse riding through the desert on Arabian mares. Book their trips in the UK through The Ultimate Travel Company (t heultimatetravelcompany.co.uk ) 
KE Adventure Travel offers an 8-day hike through Wadi Rum in the company of Bedouin guides, from £945, excluding flights ( keadventure.com ). Read about how to get into Petra "by the back door" on a trek organised by the same company from Dana Reserve to Petra. 
One of the most reliable sources for researching adventurous activities in Wadi Rum such as climbing is "Treks and Climbs in Wadi Rum" by Tony Howard, who has spent years visiting the area and knows it well.
